noun.description: A narrow channel dug in the ground, typically used for drainage alongside a road or the edge of a field.

examples: he was praised for ditching the coastal areas

verb.description: Get rid of or give up.
examples: plans for the road were ditched following a public inquiry
it crossed her mind to ditch her shoes and run

verb.description: Bring (an aircraft) down on water in an emergency.
examples: he was picked up by a frigate after ditching his plane in the Mediterranean

origin: Old English dīc, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch dijk ditch, dyke and German Teich pond, pool, also to dyke.
